Rationale

The  proposed  Project  will  remove  constraints  to  agricultural  productivity
by  investing  in  rural  infrastructure  in  southern  Philippines  regions  with
high poverty incidence and high agricultural potential. The Project will be
driven  by  the  needs  and  demands  of  communities  that  lack  the
infrastructure essential for them to realize the productive potential of their
land.  Proposals  emanating  from  local  government  units  (LGUs)  for
subprojects  that  meet  feasibility  criteria  will  be  eligible  for  Project
financing.  Using  fully  decentralized  implementation  arrangements,  the
Project  will  also  advance  the  decentralization  of  rural  infrastructure
planning and management.

 III. 

BACKGROUND

A. 

Sector Description

1. 

Poverty in the Rural Sector

3. 
Nearly 20 million people in the rural Philippines are poor. Poverty in the country is primarily
rural-based and is caused and sustained by weak rural and agricultural development. In 1997, the
last  year  for  which  poverty  data  are  available,  44.4  percent  of  all  rural  households  (equivalent  to
51.2 percent of the rural population) were living below the poverty line, compared to 18.5 percent in
urban areas and 32.1 percent for the country as a whole.3 The incidence of rural poverty based on
headcount data increased between 1994 and 1997, while it fell in the urban areas.4

4. 
Most of the rural poor are engaged in subsistence agriculture. They are concentrated in the
eastern-central and southern Philippines, particularly in the Bicol region, the eastern Visayas, the
Autonomous Region of Muslim Mindanao (ARMM), and central Mindanao. Given the magnitude of
rural  poverty,  any  sustainable  growth  strategy  for  the  Philippines  needs  to  emphasize  pro-poor
mechanisms  for  the  realization  of  agricultural  production  potentials  and  the  creation  of  viable
employment  and  income  opportunities  in  rural  areas,  particularly  in  the  southern  part  of  the
country.

2. 

Agriculture

Agriculture  is  the  dominant  sector  in  the  economy  of  the  Philippines.  It  contributes  20
6. 
percent of gross domestic product and more than 20 percent of total export earnings, and provides
36 percent of the labor force. About half of the population is rural, two thirds of which depends on
agriculture for a living, and the majority of the country’s poor live from subsistence agriculture and
fisheries.  The  sector  has  grown  slowly  and  unsteadily  since  the  early  1980s,  and  at  an  annual
average rate of 1.6 percent between 1995 and 1999. Low productivity, partly due to the absence of
an adequate policy framework and institutional arrangements to resolve the highly distorted price
incentive system (e.g., food price support and consumer subsidies), continues to beset the sector.5
The instability of growth is mainly due to (i) the downward trend in export prices of traditional export
crops,  (ii)  continuous  deterioration  of  intersectoral  trade,  (iii)  macroeconomic  constraints,  (iv)  a
series of natural calamities, (v) lack of internal markets, and (vi) high transport costs.

7. 
Agriculture's share of public investment averaged less than 13 percent between 1993 and
1997, compared to 69 percent for large-scale infrastructure. Although the Government's investment
in agriculture and rural infrastructure began to increase in 1995, primarily to support the adjustment
measures  for  the  country's  accession  to  the  World  Trade  Organization,  it  continues  to  be
inadequate. This has restricted the growth of the agriculture sector, compared to the industry and
services sectors, and consequently slowed the pace of development in rural areas.

8. 
The Government intends to develop the agriculture sector to achieve food security and be
competitive  in  the  international  market,  in  anticipation  of  the  full  implementation  by  2004  of  the
provisions  of  the  Uruguay  Round  agreements  on  tariffs  and  trade  agreed  with  the  World  Trade
Organization. The investments required to finance rural infrastructure and make agriculture globally
competitive  are  beyond  the  Government's  internal  resources.  Under  the  Philippine  Medium  Term
Public  Investment  Program  formulated  in  line  with  MTPDP,  the  financial  requirements  for  rural
roads  and  irrigation,  two  of  the  most  important  investments  to  increase  productivity,  amount  to
$2.56  billion  or  P115  billion  (para.  26).  Based  on  DA’s  budget  over  the  past  five  years,  the
Government can provide only about 50 percent of this investment. The majority of the balance will
have to be funded externally through official development assistance, as there are few incentives
for private sector investment in rural infrastructure.

3. 

Rural Infrastructure

9. 
A  primary  reason  for  the  poor  productivity  (and  low  profitability)  of  agriculture  is  the
inadequacy of rural infrastructure, particularly rural roads6 and irrigation. The quality and density of
rural roads make a significant difference in the cost of inputs, the quality and value of outputs, and
the provision of social services, as well as being an impediment to private sector investment. About
half  of  the  villages  in  the  country  lack  all-weather  access  to  the  provincial  and  national  road
networks. Moreover, the majority of the existing village roads are in such a poor condition that they

4. 

Local Government

11. 
The LGC introduced major changes in the governance structure of the Philippines, offering
new  opportunities  for  more  area-focused  and  integrated  participatory  development.  Under  the
LGC,  LGUs  are  charged  with  a  series  of  devolved  functions  relevant  to  the  Project,  such  as
(i) construction and maintenance of municipal roads and bridges, small landing facilities, and fish
ports; (ii) construction of communal irrigation and small water impoundment schemes, intervillage
irrigation, dikes, and drainage; and (iii) wells and spring development, water supply, and sanitation
projects.  The  LGC  also  charges  the  LGU  with  responsibility  for  community-based  infrastructure
rehabilitation programs and for repair and maintenance of LGU infrastructure facilities.

12. 
It is widely recognized that decentralization has been a success in the Philippines and has
provided the opportunity for making development better, more democratic and participatory, more
focused  on  the  needs  of  the  poor,  and  more  sustainable.  As  a  result  of  decentralization,  basic
services delivery is becoming more integrated, more focused on local priorities, and more efficient
and cost effective. LGUs are interested in providing more investment and maintenance support for
projects they themselves identify, construct, and own. While devolution moves project identification
and  implementation  closer  to  beneficiaries,  it  also  introduces  new  challenges,  particularly  with
regard to LGU commitment and capability. LGUs are, however, in the best position to ensure that
subprojects are located and designed most appropriately and involve the beneficiaries themselves
in the identification, development, and operation of the facilities. Experience has clearly shown that
a centralized national government cannot effectively carry out these functions in rural areas.

13. 
Although LGUs have been given many key responsibilities, capital expenditures at this level
are  low  due  to  a  lack  of  financial  resources.  The  results  of  a  recent  empirical  study  reveal  that

prevailing before devolution.9 Since 1994, spending levels are at par with 1991 levels in real terms
per capita. Among the economic sectors, agriculture suffered most, with spending lower than 1991
levels in both 1993 and 1994. To balance underfinanced LGUs, the Government provides grants to

Visayas, Mindanao, and the island provinces of Region IV.11 Subprojects will be located in areas
traditionally  neglected  by  infrastructure  investment,  where  the  incidence  of  poverty  is  relatively
high,  and  where  agricultural  growth  potential  is  visible.  Under  the  sector  approach  taken  by  the
Project, individual LGUs will have to satisfy eligibility criteria to be included in the Project.

15. 
Three factors influenced the selection of regions to be included in the Project: (i) agricultural
potential,  (ii)  historic  inequity  in  the  distribution  of  investment  in  rural  infrastructure,  and
(iii) socioeconomic development and poverty characteristics.

16.  Mindanao has a comparative advantage in agriculture over most of the rest of the country.
Because of its topography and typhoon-free climate, a wide range of annual and perennial crops
can  be  cultivated,  including  temperate  vegetables  at  higher  elevations.  Not  only  large-scale
agricultural  producers,  plantation  owners,  and  international  corporations,  but  also  small-  and
medium-scale  producers  and  cooperatives,  have  established  links  with  export  markets  for  farm
produce. Region IV’s Occidental Mindoro, Oriental Mindoro, Marinduque, and Romblon provinces
are noted for their agricultural and fishery potential. With their proximity to Metro Manila, they have
a higher degree of agri-industrialization than the Project’s other regions outside Mindanao. Eastern
Visayas  ranks  second  (after  Region  IV)  in  the  area  of  available  land  classified  by  the  Bureau  of
Soils  and  Water  Management  as  in  the  wet  agroclimatic  zone.  In  this  zone,  annual  rainfall  is
greater than 2,500 millimeters; hence the zone can readily grow two crops a year. The lower cost
of  land  and  labor,  compared  with  most  of  Luzon,  constitute  another  agricultural  advantage  in  the
project area. Real agricultural wage rates for plantation and nonplantation agriculture in Luzon are
4.3  percent  and  10.3  percent  higher  respectively  than  in  the  southern  Philippines.  Thus,  the
opportunities  for  special  labor-dependent  crops,  such  as  pineapple,  banana,  and  mango,  whose
production is managed by private corporations, abound in the southern part of the country.

17. 
The southern Philippines, and especially Mindanao, has received a disproportionately low
share  of  public  investment  in  infrastructure  with  some  70  percent  of  the  annual  national  budget
spent in Luzon. The area of the country outside of Luzon, with 72 percent of the total population
and  80  percent  of  the  rural  population,  receives  only  about  30  percent  of  the  annual  national
budget.12 Consequently, the southern Philippines has less well-developed rural infrastructure than
the other island groups. For example, only 28.2 percent of Mindanao’s cultivated land is irrigated,
compared with nearly 44 percent in the Visayas and 49 percent in Luzon; and only 32.1 percent of
households  in  Mindanao  have  access  to  community  water  systems  and  faucets,  compared  with
nearly 35.5 percent in Visayas and 39 percent in Luzon.

18.

Philippines  as  a  whole.  In  summary,  the  project  provinces  (i)  have  a  higher  incidence  of  poor
families than average (in the ARMM, almost two thirds of the population are below the threshold);
(ii) fall well below the national average index for income per person and show a high incidence of
severe poverty; (iii) have lower population densities than average, corresponding to their relatively

1. 

Rural Productivity in the Southern Philippines

19. 
The  returns  to  the  factors  of  production,  land,  labor,  and  capital,  of  farming  in  the  project
regions are well below their potential. Stakeholders at participatory workshops held in 23 provinces
during  project  formulation  cited  many  constraints  as  responsible  for  these  poor  returns,  including
(i) high  costs  of  transporting  farm  inputs  to  farms  and  products  to  markets,  (ii)  low  prices  for
marketed  products,  (iii)  lack  of  irrigation  facilities  on  some  irrigable  land,  (iv)  high  cost  of  crop
inputs  and  insufficient  capital  with  which  to  finance  their  purchase,  (v)  high  post-harvest  losses,
(vi) a  low  level  of  technology  linked  with  a  poorly-functioning  agricultural  extension  service,
(vii) tenant  farmers’  lack  of  collateral  that  could  be  provided  against  credit  for  the  purchase  of
inputs, (viii) an average size of holding that precludes economies of scale and the efficient use of
farm machinery, (ix) poor health of some farmers and their families, and (x) time spent in fetching
and carrying water. Many of these constraints can be directly or indirectly ascribed to the absence
of adequate rural infrastructure.

2.

substandard  workmanship  and  materials  used  in  construction,  poor  maintenance,  and  in  some

C. 

Government Policies and Plans

23. 
The  Government  is  committed  to  modernizing  agriculture  and  to  transforming  the
agriculture  sector  into  an  important  source  of  growth  and  the  basis  for  sustainable  rural
development.  It  intends  to  promote  higher-value  crops,  value-added  processing,  agribusiness
activities,  and  agro-industrialization  through  the  appropriate  use  of  technology  and  provision  of
incentives. It seeks to enhance competitiveness in both domestic and foreign markets and attract
private  investments  by  adopting  more  market-oriented  policies  and  providing  adequate  public
infrastructure facilities.

24. 
These  objectives  and  principles  are  enshrined  in  RA  8435  of  1997,  the  Agriculture  and
Fisheries  Modernization  Act  (AFMA)  and  its  implementing  rules  and  regulations  issued  by  DA  in

Consistent with RA 8425, the AFMA dictates that poverty alleviation and social equity are to

to  resources,  income  opportunities,  basic  and  support  services,  and  infrastructure,  especially  in

sectors  of  society.”  Food  security  is  also  to  be  given  high  priority  to  assure  the  availability,
adequacy, accessibility, and affordability of food supplies to all at all times.

26. 
The AFMA recognizes the critical role of agriculture and rural development in the reduction
of poverty and acknowledges the barriers to such development. In response to these constraints,
the  AFMA  puts  great  priority  on  the  planning  and  programming  of  rural  infrastructure  through
multisectoral  consultations  involving  the  Government,  NGOs,  people’s  organizations,  and  the
private  sector.  For  example,  medium-  and  long-term  comprehensive  agriculture  and  fisheries
modernization  plans  (AFMP)  have  been  prepared  by  DA  using  participatory  methods  and
incorporating  municipal,  provincial,  and  regional  plans  which,  in  turn,  are  based  on  a  process  of
stakeholder and beneficiary consultation. The medium-term AFMP serves as the Agricultural and
Fisheries Sector Development Plan in the MTPDP. The AFMP also covers the medium-term and
annual Agriculture and Fisheries Sector Public Investment Program (AFSPIP) that is incorporated
into the Philippine Medium Term Public Investment Program.

27. 
The  AFMA  also  mandates  that  DA  work  with  its  partner  LGUs  in  developing  plans  for
infrastructure for agriculture and fisheries, and strengthening their engineering groups to implement
these plans expeditiously. DA is expected to collaborate with other concerned NGAs to accelerate
capability building of LGUs to enable them to fulfill their responsibilities under the LGC.

28. 
There has been substantial underinvestment in the agriculture sector and LGUs have been
unable  to  provide  the  necessary  agricultural  services  and  infrastructure  on  their  own.  AFMA,
therefore,  emphasizes  the  need  for  partnership  and,  in  some  cases,  transitional  arrangements,
between  LGUs  and  the  concerned  NGAs.  These  are  necessary  to  ensure  that  the  required
technical  and  managerial  expertise,  in  addition  to  financial  and  other  resources,  are  made
available,  while  resolving  issues  related  to  the  flow  of  foreign  loans  and  grants  to  LGUs.  In  the
case  of  irrigation,  the  AFMA  specifies  that  NIA  should  continue  to  be  responsible  for  the  major
irrigation  structures  of  national  irrigation  systems  (NISs),  while  it  should  gradually  turn  over  the
secondary  canals  and  on-farm  facilities  of  NISs  to  irrigators’  associations  (IAs).  The  planning,
design, and management of communal irrigation systems (CISs) and communal irrigation projects
(CIPs)  are  to  be  devolved  to  the  LGUs.  Likewise,  the  budget  for  construction,  operation,  and
maintenance  of  CISs  and  CIPs  should  be  prepared  by  and  routed  through  LGUs.  NIA  should
continue to provide technical assistance as long as necessary. LGUs are also mandated to make
rural  roads  a  priority  investment  and  provide  at  least  10  percent  of  project  cost,  subject  to  their
internal revenue allotment level.

34. 
The most important problem that has been noted, whether the projects involve rural roads,
communal  irrigation,  or  water  supply,  is  the  failure  to  ensure  the  sustainable  operation  and
continued  maintenance  of  the  facilities  created.  This  was  generally  due  to  (i)  the  lack  of
involvement  and  participation  of  the  communities  that  were  the  supposed  beneficiaries  of  the
project,  and  (ii)  the  lack  of  LGU  involvement  and  committed  counterpart  funds  for  O&M.  It  is
therefore  important  that  (i)  targeted  beneficiaries  and  potential  users  be  organized  and  involved
from  the  very  beginning  of  the  project  cycle,  from  project  identification  and  site  selection  through
project  design  and 
implementation;  and  (ii)  LGUs  and  end-users  have  clearly  defined
responsibilities for O&M of facilities that are agreed upon in advance. A participatory, community-
based  approach  to  project  planning  and  implementation  is  a  major  prerequisite  for  ensuring  the
quality  and  sustainability  of  small-scale  infrastructure  in  rural  areas.  Such  an  approach  will  also
make the project less susceptible to change in political leadership and development priorities.

35.  More  than  just  the  beneficiary  communities  themselves,  the  concerned  LGUs  should  be
actively involved in the process and committed to the provision of O&M. They should not merely be
consulted, but be the lead implementers of projects. The LGC recognizes the difficulties inherent in
having  rural  infrastructure  projects  provided  and  maintained  by  the  national  government.  While
NGAs  should  continue  to  provide  policy  guidance  and  technical  support,  the  concerned  LGU
should  coordinate  with  all  participating  agencies  and  be  solely  responsible  for  the  project’s
outcome.  As  much  as  possible,  the  LGUs  should  also,  whether  singly  or  as  a  group,  take  the
initiative in prioritizing their needs and securing the financing to meet these needs.

Policy Dialogue

Policy  dialogue  during  project  preparation  has  focused  on  advancing  decentralization,

1. 

Strengthened Decentralization

38. 
Under the LGC, greater responsibilities for rural development have been devolved to LGUs.
With  LGU-led  implementation  arrangements  and  a  fully  decentralized  funds  flow  mechanism,  the
Project  will  advance  the  implementation  of  the  LGC,  particularly  the  devolution  of  responsibilities
for rural development to municipal-level LGUs. Under the Project, LGUs will be directly responsible
for  identifying,  appraising,  implementing,  and  monitoring  subprojects  while  DA  will  focus  on
providing  overall  guidance  and  policy  support.  LGU  eligibility  criteria,  supported  by  the  demand-
driven  structure,  will  ensure  that  the  participating  LGUs  have  strong  commitment  and  adequate
institutional and financial capacity to implement, maintain, and monitor the subprojects (para. 100).

39. 
To promote local autonomy in financial planning and management, the loan proceeds and
Government  counterpart  funds  for  rural  infrastructure  investments  will  be  directly  channeled  to
LGUs  through  municipal  development  fund  (MDF)  mechanisms  (or  other  mechanisms  that  are
considered appropriate at the time of project implementation).28 The Government will ensure that
adequate counterpart funds for rural infrastructure investments are allocated directly to MDF. This
will advance fiscal decentralization and increase financial accountability at the local level. To gain
strong ownership by LGUs of rural infrastructure provided under the Project, the participating LGUs
will be required to share a specific portion of the investment cost (para. 80).

40. 
To ensure that LGUs are equipped with adequate institutional and technical capabilities, the
Project  will  train  LGU  staff  in  participatory  project  planning  and  implementation,  contract
supervision  and  procurement  procedures,  and  participatory  project  benefit  monitoring  and
evaluation.

2.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A. 

Rationale

1. 

Project Rationale

45. 
Agriculture  dominates  the  economy  of  the  Philippines  despite  the  development  of
substantial manufacturing and service sectors. Even the manufacturing sector largely depends on
agriculture for its raw materials. Although 36 percent of the population depends on agriculture for
livelihood,  the  country’s  agriculture  sector  is  performing  below  its  potential,  national  economic
growth is being held back by the slow and erratic progress of agricultural development, and most of
those  engaged  in  the  sector  remain  poor.  The  Government  has  recognized  the  need  for
modernization of the sector by promulgating AFMA. The Project will complement the Government’s
plans  to  stimulate  rural  growth  by  focusing  on  traditionally  neglected  areas  with  high  agricultural
growth potential.

Inadequate rural infrastructure stands out as a principal cause of the constraints that many
46. 
poor farmers face in becoming more productive and profitable. Chief among them is the difficulty
and  cost  of  hauling  their  inputs  to  the  farm  and  their  outputs  to  market  caused  by  the  lack  of
access infrastructure (including rural roads, landings, etc.). In extreme cases, farmers are inhibited
from  planting  any  crops  on  their  land,  or  grow  only  that  which  is  sufficient  for  their  subsistence
needs.  In  others,  farmers  are  deterred  from  switching  to  higher  value  crops  because  of  the
bulkiness  of  some,  such  as  fruit  and  vegetables.  Yields  are  below  potential  because  insufficient

 11

inputs  are  applied.  Gross  margins  of  farm  enterprises  are  reduced  by  the  cost  of  haulage.29  The
absence of irrigation infrastructure where both suitable land (with regard to soils and topography)
and sufficient water coexist, prevents the land from attaining its full productive and profit potential.
The members of some rural communities are unable to be as productive as they should because of
either  waterborne  diseases  caused  by  polluted  drinking  water  or  the  time  spent  in  fetching  water
from  a  distant  source.  The  main  thrust  of  the  Project  will  be  to  remove  these  constraints  in  the
project area. This approach is consistent with ADB’s sectoral strategy, which recognizes improved
rural infrastructure as the key to sustainable rural development and poverty reduction.

Since  1991  and  the  advent  of  the  LGC,  the  Philippines  has  been  undergoing  a  major
47. 
decentralization process, where provincial and municipal LGUs are being made more responsible
for rural development, while NGAs assume the roles of facilitator and supporter. To enable LGUs
to  discharge  these  new  responsibilities,  resource  transfers  from  NGAs  to  LGUs  have  increased,
particularly  since  the  mid-1990s.  However,  full  financial  decentralization  has  yet  to  be  realized  in
social  and  urban  services  and  in  the  agriculture  sector.  The  Project  addresses  this  challenge  by
making  LGUs responsible for rural infrastructure investments and shifting DA’s concentration to its
core functions of policy formulation, monitoring, and analysis. The Project will thus contribute to the
promotion of good governance in addition to agricultural growth and rural poverty reduction.

48. 
The  Project  will  adopt  an  approach  that  differs  in  many  respects  from  that  of  earlier
Government and ADB interventions in the rural sector.  It will be driven by the needs and demands
of communities that lack the infrastructure essential for them to realize the productive potential of
their  land.  Proposals  emanating  from  LGUs  for  subprojects  that  meet  financial,  economic,  and
poverty  reduction-related  eligibility  criteria  will  be  considered  for  acceptance  by  the  Project  for
financing  and  implementation.  This  demand-driven  sector  approach  will  reduce  the  risk  that
interventions  either  do  not  meet  the  priorities  of  the  recipient  community  or  do  not  achieve
expected gains in productivity because communities had no sense of ownership, with consequent
failure to operate or maintain the infrastructure adequately.30

49. 
The  Project  concept  also  assumes  that  in  many  areas  the  provision  of  an  element  of
infrastructure  will  complete  a  system  and  enable  substantial  gains  in  productivity  to  be  realized.
Completed,  ongoing,  or  planned  programs/projects  in  the  project  area  offer  opportunities  for
synergy  and  consequently,  gains  in  productivity  can  be  greater  than  where  subprojects  are
implemented  in  isolation.  Eligibility  criteria  are  framed  to  exclude  LGUs  where  competing  or
overlapping projects are being or will be implemented, but to allow for the inclusion of subprojects
that will generate synergy with other interventions in the area.

141.  For  irrigation  development,  the  financial  analysis  shows  the  expected  impact  of  Project

investments in rural roads the expected impact on production at the farm level has been assessed

provision of improved access.

4. 

Economic Analysis

145.  The economic internal rates of return (EIRR) for individual road investments range from 14
to  30  percent  with  an  overall  value  of  19  percent. The  analyses  show  that  where  the  EIRR  is  at
least  20  percent,  the  returns  are  not  unduly  sensitive  to  changes  in  the  key  variables.  Of  the
variables analyzed, the results are most sensitive to the assumption concerning the average length
of  journey.  Returns  are  less  sensitive  to  the  level  of  investment  costs  and  savings  in  transport
costs. Transport cost savings vary widely and depend upon the extent to which higher-cost modes
of  transport  (i.e.,  animal  and  human  transport)  are  replaced  by  lower-cost  motorized  transport.
Finally,  returns  are  insensitive  to  the  costs  of  maintenance  or  to  the  assumptions  concerning  the
level  of  agricultural  output  as  nonagricultural  freight  and  passenger  traffic  provide  important
contributions to the savings in transport costs.

146.  The  investment  in  irrigation  based  on  the  subproject  models  gives  an  overall  EIRR  of
34 percent. Project investments that will rehabilitate and/or extend existing schemes show higher
economic returns (up to 65 percent), as there are high levels of sunk costs, while the returns from
new construction are lower at 16 to 22 percent. Returns are mostly insensitive to changes in key
variables.  However,  if  the  future  rice  price  were  the  equivalent  of  the  bottom  value  of  the
70 percent  probability  range  indicated  by  the  World  Bank,  estimates  of  the  viability  of  irrigation
development would be seriously undermined, with only four schemes remaining marginally viable.
Scheme  implementation  should  consider  crop  diversification  as  one  way  of  reducing  the  risks
associated with possible reductions in future rice prices.

147.  Assuming  that  the  results  of  the  core  subprojects  represent  the  potential  returns  from  all
project investments and after including all the costs associated with capacity building and project
management  and  coordination,  the  overall  EIRR  will  be  18  percent  with  net  present  values,
discounted at 12 and 15 percent, respectively,70 of P=1,069 million and P=400 million.

148.  Additional  analyses  have  also  been  prepared,  the  first  using  0.83  as  the  SCF  which

B. 

Estimated Impact on Poverty

150.  The  Project  will  be  implemented  in  approximately  100  LGUs  (1,200  villages)  across  the
project area. The geographic coverage and the selection criteria for LGU participants ensure that
the Project will provide infrastructure in rural areas where nearly half of the households are poor.
Based  on  an  analysis  of  the  core  subprojects,  it  is  estimated  that  the  Project  will  directly  benefit
some  700,000  people  (50  percent  of  which  being  poor)  and  indirectly  benefit  another  160,000
people (47 percent of which being poor). By project completion, at least 90,000 people should be
lifted  out  of  poverty.  Approximately  1,000  person-years  of  incremental  employment  will  be
generated, 57 percent of which is expected to benefit the poor.

151.  However,  only  about  0.4  percent  of  the  poverty-reduction  impact  can  be  attributed  to  the
income generated from construction or maintenance of the infrastructure, while the remaining 99.6
percent is due to its usage. On a subsectoral basis, 67 percent of the long-term poverty-reduction
impact  is  due  to  access  infrastructure  (with  approximately  51  percent  of  the  investment  cost),  19
percent  due  to  irrigation  (with  approximately  41  percent  of  the  investment  cost),  and  14  percent
due to potable water supply (with approximately 8 percent of the investment cost). An analysis of
potential beneficiaries shows that access infrastructure is the most effective way to reduce poverty
in  the  rural  Philippines,  while  irrigation  shows  the  smallest  impact.  This  is  mainly  because  many
irrigation  users  and  beneficiaries  are  not  below  the  poverty  line.  Additionally,  potable  water
schemes are a highly effective means of addressing rural poverty in the Philippines, although most
of the impact is on income poverty (additional time for agricultural production) rather than human
poverty (reduction in waterborne diseases).

152.  The  Project  will  have  only  marginal  poverty-reduction  impact  at  the  national  level  (an
estimated reduction from 35.7 percent of rural poverty incidence in 2000 to 35.6 percent in 2008).
At the village and municipal level, however, the poverty-reduction impact will be substantial: from
estimated  60  percent  incidence  in  2000  to  49  percent  in  2008  for  the  targeted  villages  and
municipalities.  Appendix  11  provides  a  summary  poverty  impact  assessment  including  the
underlying assumptions.

C. 

Social Dimensions

153.  A social impact assessment was conducted during project formulation. During this process,
comprehensive consultations with beneficiaries were undertaken and surveys were carried out in
all core subproject sites. Through the provision of improved rural road infrastructure, the Project will
directly  and  indirectly  help  reduce  poverty  in  the  project  area.  Improved  accessibility  will  lead  to
more reliable and efficient flow of goods and people, incentives to increase agricultural production,
and  increased  labor  mobility,  all  of  which  will  result  in  additional  employment  and  incomes
(Appendix 11).

154. 
Indirect social benefits to communities that gain access through better roads will include (i)
improved educational attendance by primary and secondary school students, and (ii) better access
to  health  facilities.  In  addition,  specific  measures  have  been  included  in  the  project  design  and
implementation  arrangements  to  ensure  that  employment  and  business  opportunities  will  be
provided  to  local  people  to  enhance  their  incomes  by  participating  in  road  rehabilitation  and
maintenance activities.

155.  Construction  and  rehabilitation  of  small  irrigation  schemes  will  increase  agricultural
production  significantly.  Irrigation  can  provide  farmers  with  one  additional  crop  per  year.  As  the
criteria for selecting subprojects include poverty indicators, small-scale farmers will benefit from the
Project  in  particular.  Increased  agricultural  production  will  also  benefit  landless  farmers  as  it  is
anticipated that middle size and large farmers will require additional labor input.

156.  The  Project  will  benefit  women  in  particular  by  improving  access  to  drinking  water.  The
provision of water supplies can reduce the time spent collecting water and can lead to better health
both through the quality of drinking water and improved hygiene.

D. 

Project Risks

157.  With  a  history  of  poor  revenue  collection,  the  Government  faces  frequent  budget  deficits.
With devolution, LGUs are increasingly burdened with new responsibilities for which they often do
not have adequate counterpart funds for investment or maintenance. This is particularly true for the
poorer  LGUs,  which  are  the  main  recipients  of  investment  under  the  Project.  Furthermore,  the
funds  that  the  LGUs  will  be  required  to  contribute  to  the  financing  of  subprojects  could  result  in
crowding out of other necessary investments, particularly in the social sectors. This could result in
delays  in  project  implementation  and  have  a  negative  impact  on  other  LGU  and  Government
development and poverty reduction goals.

158.  Devolution of agricultural services and rural infrastructure facilities to LGUs as provided by
the LGC and AFMA presents both a challenge and an opportunity. While devolution moves project
identification and implementation closer to beneficiaries, it also introduces an additional element of
uncertainty,  particularly  as  regards  commitment  and  capability.  The  financial,  technical,  and
managerial  capacity  of  LGUs  to  implement  these  projects  is  recognized  to  be  limited.  LGUs,
however,  are  in  the  best  position  to  make  sure  that  subprojects  are  located  and  designed  most
appropriately  and  involve  the  beneficiaries  themselves  in  the  identification  of  needs  and  O&M  of
the completed facilities. Experience has clearly shown that the Government cannot effectively carry
out these functions.

159.  The  risks  arising  from  the  implementation  capacity  of  the  LGUs,  changes  in  political
leadership  and  priorities,  and  the  maintenance  capability  of  LGUs  and  of  the  beneficiaries
themselves will be mitigated by timely, appropriate, and effective capability-building activities that
the  Project  will  finance.  Participatory  planning,  as  implemented  under  IRAP,  will  ensure  that
beneficiary  communities  are  committed  to  the  subproject.  This  commitment  will  result  in
subprojects that are less susceptible to political change, more likely to be maintained properly, and
appropriate to the implementation capacity of the LGU.

Lessons Learned from ADB-Assisted Projects

Incorporation of Lessons Learned

A. Capacity of Community Organizations
•  Establishment of effective beneficiary

organizations is critical to ensure that the
facilities built under the project lead the
intended impact (Loans 528/529[SF]-PHI:
Palawan Integrated Area Development).
•  Sufficient inputs need to be provided for
developing beneficiary organizations to
effectively manage facilities (Loan 802-PHI:
Highland Agriculture Development).
•  Forming community-level water users
associations and building capacity for
improving their skills should precede the
actual construction of the facility. (Loan
1052[SF]-PHI: Second Island Province Rural
Water Supply Sector).

B. Beneficiary Participation

• 

Involvement of the potential beneficiaries in
designing irrigation structures is essential to
generate a sense of ownership and to benefit
from their experience and knowledge of local
geotechnical conditions (Loan 466-PHI:
Second Laguna de Bay Irrigation).

•  Beneficiary participation in the planning and
design of project components can improve
the relevance of project-supplied facilities to
the needs of the beneficiaries (Loan 802-PHI:
Highland Agriculture Development).
•  The process of site selection needs to be
more demand-driven. The process of
consultations with local communities and
local government unites should be
strengthened and structured (Loan 812-PHI:
Island Province Rural Water Supply Sector).

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT PLAN

A.

Introduction

1. 
The primary component of the Project is improving rural infrastructure. Rural infrastructure
includes  rural  roads  and  other  transport  links,  communal  irrigation  systems,  and  potable  water
supply facilities. Ten core subprojects have been identified and assessed in terms of resettlement
and  land  acquisition  issues.  The  assessment  indicated  that  none  of  the  10  core  subprojects  are
expected to have a significant impact in terms of resettlement.

The summary resettlement plan provides an estimate of cost based on design data for two
2. 
core subprojects, the first in the municipality of Kapalong, Davao del Norte, and the second in the
municipality of Mainit, Surigao del Norte. Additional survey work will need to be prepared to assess
the land acquisition requirements when the design work has been finalized for all subprojects.

3. 
For  subprojects  where  resettlement  impacts  are  anticipated,  the  resettlement  plan  will  be
updated prior to commencing works. Receipt of the updated final resettlement plan acceptable to
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will be a condition for commencing construction.

B. 

Resettlement Policy

4. 
Resettlement will be implemented according to legislation of the Government of Philippines
and in accordance with ADB policy on involuntary resettlement (November 1995).  The basis under
the Constitution and laws of the Republic of the Philippines are as follows: (i) The 1987 Philippine
Constitution;  (ii)  Executive  Order  1035  (1985);  (iii)  Administrative  Order  65,  Series  of  1983;
(iv) Republic Act 6389; and (iv) Administrative Order 50 (1999).

C.

Minimization of Resettlement Impact

5. 
The Project will adopt a policy of minimizing adverse resettlement impacts and reducing the
number  of  affected  persons  by  continuously  reviewing  the  design  to  further  minimize  land
acquisition and resettlement requirements.

D. 

Resettlement Impacts

There  is  only  insignificant  impact  in  terms  of  resettlement  in  the  two  core  subprojects
6. 
assessed. In the Mainit subproject, 23 people are likely to be affected. The Mainit subproject has
two components: communal irrigation, and construction and rehabilitation of rural roads (9.4 km).
Three people are likely to be affected because of relocation of their residences and acquisition of
agricultural land; 19 landowners and 1 tenant farmer are likely to be affected by land acquisition for
the rural road projects. The total land for acquisition for road right-of-way is 1.26 ha.

7. 
In  the  municipality  of  Kapalong  subproject,  20  people  are  likely  to  be  affected.  The
components  of  the  subproject  consist  of  upgrading  of  rural  roads  with  a  total  length  of  24.5  km
expansion  of  two  communal  irrigation  systems,  and  construction  of  one  communal  irrigation
system. Eight people are likely to be affected by the relocation of their residential households and
12 are likely to be affected by land acquisition for the irrigation projects. One person whose house
needs relocation may lose livelihood and income. Total land acquisition is about 3 ha affecting 12
people for the construction of a communal irrigation system dam and the construction of a bridge.

E.

Consistent with the Government’s and ADB’s policy, affected people will be assisted to
8.

Project. All possible means will be explored to minimize resettlement impacts through modification
of the engineering designs. This will be carried out in close consultation with the affected people.
Plans for acquisition of land and other assets will be implemented in consultation with the affected

villages. Legal owners and tenants of land will be compensated and assisted with rehabilitation. No

SOCIAL DIMENSIONS AND POVERTY ASSESSMENT

A. 

Poverty and Social Characteristics

1. 
During  the  15  years  prior  to  the  Asian  economic  crises,  poverty  incidence  in  the
Philippines had declined by 12.1 percent. In 1997, the latest year for which Family Income and
Expenditure  Survey  data  are  available,  32.1  percent  or  4.5  million  families  had  income  below
the  poverty  threshold,  and  44.4  percent  of  rural  households  (equivalent  to  51.2  percent  of  the
rural  population)  fell  below  the  threshold.  By  headcount,  37.5  percent  of  the  population  was
below  the  poverty  line  in  1997,  equivalent  to  27.25  million  people.1  In  the  project  area,  the
poverty incidence ranges between 49.0 and 63.6 percent, which is substantially higher than the
national  average  of  37.5  percent.2  The  severity  of  poverty  is  also  higher.  Between  24  and  37
percent  of  the  population  in  the  project  area  are  severely  poor  with  income  under  the  food
threshold, compared to 20 percent for the Philippines as a whole (Table A11.1). Rural poverty is
most  common  among  (i)  lowland  landless  agricultural  workers,  tenants,  and  leaseholders;
(ii) lowland small farm owners and cultivators; (iii) upland farmers on steeply sloped land; and
(iv) fisherfolk.

Social  indicators  are  also  low  in  the  Project  area:  the  average  value  of  the  life
2. 
expectancy index for the Philippines is 0.72, and the lowest value in one of the provinces of the
project area (Tawi-Tawi) is 0.47.  The project area has higher than average infant mortality than
the nation as a whole and the infant mortality rate in the project regions include the worst in the
Philippines. Diaerrheal diseases are the main cause of death among children younger than five,
with lack of clean water supplies clearly contributing to a high infant mortality rate. The human
development  index  (HDI)  ranges  between  0.491  for  the  Autonomous  Region  of  Muslim
Mindanao  and  0.673  for  the  island  provinces  of  Southern  Tagalog,  compared  to  0.740  for  the
Philippines as a whole.3

3. 
Smallholder agricultural potential is constrained by (i) unequal land distribution; (ii) lack
of access to basic inputs, transport, and storage facilities; (iii) the general decline of agricultural
extension  services;  (iv)  difficulty  in  accessing  markets;  and  (v)  risks  due  to  natural  calamities
such as La Niña and El Niño. The average size of farms tilled by the landless is 0.75 hectares
(ha)  and  the  average  landholding  is  1.5  ha,  with  the  poor  farmers  having  land  holdings  of
between 1.0 and 2.5 ha. Land is more equitably distributed in Mindanao than in Eastern Visayas
and  Bicol.  Common  crops  produced  by  landless  farmers  and  smallholders  are  rice,  coconut,
corn, and vegetables. Periods of extreme deprivation occur when there is no work at all, usually
between the planting and harvesting seasons. Only a few have access to agricultural equipment
and facilities. Due to their low income, the poor often depend on larger landowners for credit to
cover as much as 80 percent of their required farm inputs such as seed and fertilizer. The cost
of fertilizer in 1998-1999 was reported to have increased in the Philippines by 30 percent to as
much as 60 percent.4

4. 
Families  in  the  upland  areas,  often  indigenous  peoples,  are  particularly  poor.  These
communities  mainly  suffer  from  the  perils  and  risks  posed  by  bad  roads  and  nonexistent
bridges.  In  the  upland  areas  of  the  project  area,  particularly  in  Mindanao,  residents  walk,  use
animals,  or  use  motorcycles  as  the  basic  modes  of  transportation.  This  is  inefficient  and  the
costs  are  high,  primarily  due  to  the  limited  capacity  to  carry  agricultural  products.  Motorcycle
operators  usually  demand  high  fares  even  for  short  distances.  The  poor  and  smallholders
depend heavily on the motorcycles, which are often the only way of marketing their products. To
reduce expenditures, women and child labor (often unpaid) is used for transporting agricultural
products  to  markets.  As  a  result,  children  are  often  absent  from  school  or  drop  out.  Improved
transportation  is  particularly  important  for  reducing  income  and  human  poverty  among  these
upland residents.

5. 
In fishing communities, low productivity is associated with low fish stocks, resulting from
uncontrolled and often illegal fishing and poaching, the control of which is often not enforced. In
the coastal areas, a day‘s catch only fetches an average income of P50, which is not sufficient
for  the  household’s  daily  food  requirements.  Some  fisherfolk  have  expressed  the  need  to
establish fish sanctuaries, construct landing and storage facilities, and have access to financial
assistance for the acquisition of boats and other fishing provisions. However, poverty in fishing
communities  may  only  be  overcome  by  providing  new  income  opportunities  as  alternatives  to
traditional fishing.

B. 

Social Dimensions

1. 

Vulnerability of Women and Children

6. 
The generally favorable indicators of women’s education, health, and work participation
in  the  Philippines  mask  a  number  of  gender  issues.  Women  in  rural  areas  are  typically
responsible for the household, the children, and small livestock. In fishing communities they are
often responsible for selling fish. Single parent households, composed of widows and widowers,
many  of  whom  are  elderly,  depend  on  farming  and  pension  pay  for  their  subsistence.  Others
rely on the support of children working as domestic servants in towns and cities.

7. 
Women  and  children  (both  sexes)  are  also  often  responsible  for  fetching  water.  The
provision  of  water  supply  can  reduce  the  time  spent  collecting  water  and  can  lead  to  better
health, both through the quality of drinking water and improved hygiene. It can, however, also
lead  to  environmental  and  health  problems  if  proper  drainage  and  sanitation  are  not  used.
Roads  are  of  particular  benefit  to  women,  providing  better  access  to  education  and  health
services, to vendors of household goods, and to markets for small livestock.

2. 

Indigenous People

The project area in Mindanao comprises a good number of the indigenous peoples and
8. 
the  settlers  (mainly  from  Cebu  and  the  Visayas).  In  the  past,  indigenous  peoples  depended
heavily  on  forest  resources  for  food,  as  they  are  traditionally  hunters  and  gatherers.  Many  of
them are now subsistence farmers, using the slash-and-burn system. Common crops grown are
coconut,  coffee,  and  sweet  potato.  However,  mainly  because  of  poor  access  infrastructure,
many  indigenous  peoples  live  outside  the  regular  market  economy  and  out  of  reach  of
agricultural  extension  and  health  and  education  services.  Poor  market  access,  forest
degradation, health problems, and illiteracy are still the principal causes of their deprivation and
impoverishment.

Resettlement Issues

Resettlement  effects  are  not  anticipated  to  be  significant  in  the  Project.  However,
9. 
reflecting  the  importance  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  places  on  careful  and  effective
implementation,  a  resettlement  and  compensation  plan  will  be  prepared  based  on  ADB

4. 

Participatory Development

10. 
The project design is driven by the needs and demands of the communities that lack the
infrastructure  important  for  them  to  realize  the  productive  potential  of  their  land.  Subproject
selection  is  based  on  participatory  consultations  at  the  village  level  in  conjunction  with  the
municipal  administration  and  local  nongovernment  organizations  and  peoples’  organizations.
These stakeholders will also be involved in project preparation, implementation, and monitoring
and  evaluation.  Women  will  have  an  equal  opportunity  to  participate  in  project  activities,  and
they will be adequately represented in training and other project activities.

Expected Poverty Reduction Impact of the Project5

The  economic  impacts  of  infrastructure  projects  have  been  identified  as  follows:  lower
11. 
prices,  better  marketing  opportunities,  higher  profits  (the  price  level  for  fruit  and  vegetables  is
approximately  20  percent  higher  at  town  markets  than  at  local  market),  more  employment
opportunities  (including  construction  and  maintenance  of  project  roads),  all  leading  to  higher
gross  domestic  product  growth  rate.  Improved  access  to  drinking  water  will  not  only  improve
health  standards,  but  also  reduce  the  time  spent  on  collecting  water.  Without  the  basic  road
infrastructure,  it  is  difficult  to  access  health  and  educational  services,  which  are  presently
inaccessible in much of the project area. While most direct benefits are in the form of reduced
transportation costs, the profits of middlemen acting as intermediates between the farmers and
the  market  (and  currently  dominating  the  marketing  structure  in  some  project  areas)  will  be
more equally shared among the poor.

General Approach to Financial and Economic Analysis

1. 
Financial and economic analyses have been carried out for the 10 core subprojects developed

1. 

Financial Analysis

2. 
Financial analyses were carried out from the viewpoint of the participant farming households
and irrigator’s associations (IAs).1 For irrigation development the analysis shows the expected impact
of project investments in providing an assured supply of water on the income from crop production for
a  household  with  an  average  sized  holding.  The  analysis  also  shows  the  impact  of  operations  and
maintenance (O&M) costs, loan repayments, and income from irrigation fees on the cash flow of the
IAs  responsible  for  operating  and  maintaining  the  communal  irrigation  schemes.  For  investments  in
rural  roads  the  expected  impact  on  production  at  the  farm  level  has  been  assessed  based  on
experience elsewhere in the project area.

2. 

Economic Analysis

The  economic  analysis  for  the  Project  assumes  that  the  costs  and  benefits  of  the  10  core
3. 
subprojects for which feasibility studies have been undertaken will be representative of all those to be
financed from the Project loan. The period of analysis for each year’s infrastructure investment is 20
years,  reflecting  the  economic  life  of  rural  roads  and  communal  irrigation  systems  and  communal
irrigation projects.2

4. 
The  Asian  Development  Bank  normally  uses  12  percent  as  the  opportunity  cost  of  capital
(OCC) for  its developing member  countries. Using the model developed by the Harvard Institute for
International Development (HIID)3 the OCC was 11.5 percent in 1993 and more recent economic data
gives a figure of around 12 percent. This latter figure has been used when assessing the economic
viability  of  the  Project.  However,  this  analysis  uses  15  percent  when  assessing  the  viability  of  the
subprojects and their components. Such an approach allows for the inclusion of the costs of capacity
building  and  project  coordination  and  management  that  are  required  to  realize  the  benefits  of  the
subproject investments and  can not be allocated to individual subprojects. Therefore, all subproject
investments  should  show  a  minimum  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  of  15  percent  to  be
eligible for funding from project sources to give an overall project return in excess of 12 percent.

5. 
The  economic  analysis  has  been  carried  out  in  the  national  currency  with  traded  goods  and
services  valued  at  either  their  free  on  board  (fob)  or  cost,  insurance,  and  freight  (cif)  values,  as
appropriate.  The  World  Bank  Commodity  Markets  and  the  Developing  Countries  report  (April  2000)
has  been  used  to  provide  price  estimates  for  those  project  commodities  that  are  widely  traded  (rice
and fertilizers). Using the model developed by HIID3 and 1997 data (the latest available) gives 0.91 as
the standard  conversion factor (SCF) and the analysis uses this value to revalue the financial prices
of  all  nontraded  goods  and  services.  For  unskilled  labor  the  economic  analysis  uses  the  financial
opportunity cost based on the prevailing wage rates in the subproject areas (i.e., P110/day reduced to
P90/day) to reflect the extent to which labor is unemployed or underemployed multiplied by the SCF.
On this basis the conversion factor for labor is 0.68 equivalent to an economic cost of P75 per day.

31.  @RISK software was used to analyze the impact of uncertainty concerning key variables on
the  returns  from  the  proposed  investments  in  rural  roads  and  irrigation  development  (rehabilitation

simulation  techniques  recalculates  the  road  and  irrigation  spreadsheets  included  in  the  feasibility
studies 100 or more times and presents the results.

nearly  19  percent  and  the  modal  values  18-19  percent.  The  results  for  irrigation  show  a  wider
variation with minimum values of 26-27 percent and maximum values of 42-44 percent. The mean is
34 percent and the mode 33 percent.
